B000002I6T|5.0|Everyone seems to have an opinion on David Crosby. Due to his drug antics, his prison stint, his sperm donating: well, the tabloid stuff seems to outweigh his music career.  <br /> <br />This is his great redeeming record, however, a mere 9 song cycle that's worth every penny. Haunting doesn't even begin to describe the sound of it. It has a great early-seventies sound, found on albums by other artists of the time like CSN, Neil Young, the Dead and others. Something about the pre-amps or compressors they were using in studios in those days. Far superior in sound to most of what's around today. <br /> <br />\\"Music Is Love\\" is a bit of a pleasant throwaway, admitedly. It's just the warm up. The 7 or 8 minute \\"Cowboy Movie\\" is what really launches this record, with Crosby singing crytptically about some incident (a drug bust?) over a funky, spiky riff reminicient of something off of Neil Young's \\"Everybody Knows This Is Nowhere\\". \\"Cowboy Movie\\" shouldn't work as a song, but it does, and it just sets up what's to come. \\"Tamalpais High\\", \\"Laughing\\", \\"What Are Their Names\\", \\"Song WIth No Words\\". Brilliant stuff--Crosby proves that even when he has no lyrics he can get under your skin (like on the jazzy \\"Tamalpais..\\"). \\"Laughing\\" on here is particularly effective. It's actually the most logical continuation of his work with the Byrds (the \\"Younger Than Yestarday\\" and \\"Notorious Byrd Bros.\\" albums). By the time you come to \\"Orleans\\", you will probably already be awed, but \\"Orleans\\" is yet another great song. The whole thing wraps up with \\"I Could Swear There Was Somone Here\\". The story goes that Crosby laid down that song very sponteneously in about 3 or 4 takes of vocal overdubs (Cros. autobiography \\"Long Time Gone\\" has nice info on the recording of this LP, along with amusing tidbits and anecdotes from the engineer Stephen Barncard ). It serves as the perfect closer to this laid-back but very intense and moving album.  <br /> <br />This is material that most of Crosby's peers would've killed for. I can't say enough good things about this record--if you're a fan of the Cros. and you haven't heard this, buy it right now.

B000FQJAIW|4.0|What George Lucas doesn't seem to understand, and what no one has apparently succeeded in conveying to him thus far, is that he didn't just make a movie here.  What he did, instead, was to give an American people who were trying to figure out who they were (at the end of the counterculture revolution) a new mythology to latch onto. <br /> <br />The summer of love was almost a decade behind us.  Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin and Jim Morrison were all dead.  Peace, love and music had given way to cocaine and disco, and a new generation of kids was looking for a new purpose. <br /> <br />\\"Star Wars - A New Hope\\" made it cool for boys to want to be warriors again, just a few years after Vietnam ended in fiasco.  It also electrified millions of young people (myself included) to the possibilities that might exist beyond earth orbit, and beyond the technology of 1977. <br /> <br />Finally, it touched on that most powerful human need - to be a part of a story with real meaning and spellbinding adventure.  For the generation born in the late 60's that was too young to have been a part of the counterculture revolution, \\"Star Wars\\" was our Homer's Odyssey.  It was the tale that defined our culture and our generation.  It was our definitive mythology. <br /> <br />Nobody wants their definitive mythology messed with, even if the result is a better film.   <br /> <br />Message to George Lucas:  Please fully restore the original theatrical versions and issue them in anamorphic widescreen the way they deserve.  Nobody asked you to change our world, but you did, and became a millionaire in the process.  You started this, now please finish it by giving us properly restored DVD documents of the original versions of the three movies that changed my generation of Americans forever.

B000ETRCMQ|5.0|Felicity Huffman's transcendent, oscar-nominated portrayal of Bree, a male-to-female transexual, is a tour de force matched only by two performances in recent memory:  Hillary Swank's heartbreaking turn as a doomed \\"male\\" impersonator in \\"Boy's Don't Cry\\" and Phillip Seymour Hoffman's oscar-winning title role in last year's \\"Capote.\\"  Bree's improbable journey of self-discovery is prompted by an unexpected call from Toby (Kevin Zegers), her estranged son, a street hustler locked down in a juvenile detention center.   Forced by her sympathetic therapist (Elizabeth Pena) to confront and reconcile her past, Bree bails out the rambunctious, unsuspecting Toby, thereby embarking on a roller-coaster adventure that takes them both by surprise.  Together they set out on a cross-country trip from New York to Los Angeles, where they will part ways:  she will have her long-anticipated sex change surgery and he can pursue his dreams of tracking down his \\"real\\" father and go on to become a well-paid(porn) film star.      The stiff, proper, overeducated Bree is nicely counterbalanced by the nonjudgmental affect of her street-wise urchin of a son, who is also keenly intelligent. Along the way, we meet good Samaritan cowboys (Graham Greene), lascivious truck drivers, thieving grifters and Bree's quirky, eccentric parents, who demonstrate plausible (though improbable) unconditional love toward Bree (the comic geniuses of Burt Young and the great Fionula Flannigan--as Bree's parents--are on terrific display here).  A sweet and good-natured comedy, \\"Transamerica\\" has many pleasures:  it is full of surprising twists and, most of all, astounding performances from Huffman and Zegers.  Huffman, who lowered her voice several octaves for the duration of filming, achieves the amazing trick of erasing every trace of her considerable beauty and natural femininity--her every gesture of a gender-compromised man imitating a woman feels authentic and true-to-life!  Completely transforming herself under a mountain of unflattering (but believable) makeup, Huffman communicates a profoundly touching core of feeling for the misfit transexual on a journey for love and self-acceptance. Whatever your persuasion,   \\"Transamerica\\" will win you over!

It's glossy, high-quality and in full colour. It's definitely a good album, but I think I like Stripped a little better.

You see, we weren't told something important in the first two installments: Xavier had to \\"split\\" Jean into two personalities to protect her from her own gifts. The purely instinctual, uncontrolled, subconscious part of her was \\"The Phoenix\\". The conscious, controlled, intellectual part was the Jean we knew from the first two movies.<br /><br />If that isn't bad, she ends up disintegrating Xavier. Yes, the beloved Doctor and leader of the School for Gifted Youngsters goes out with a whimper.<br /><br />Magneto takes this uncontrollable creature under his wings (?!). She mostly stands by looking blank (I think she was supposed to look menacing) until the final confrontation. After some of the mutants are neutralized with \\"the cure\\" (a serum derived from a mutant that reverses mutations) or destroyed--THEN Phoenix suddenly goes into action, disintegrating people and objects.<br /><br />Wolverine says he's the only one that can stop her, because of his regenerative skills. Jean comes to her senses for a few seconds, and begs Wolverine to save her. Of course, he has to kill her to do so.<br /><br />Storm--a lackluster Hallie Barry--ends up taking over the school and delivering a ho-hum eulogy.<br /><br />There's so much wrong with this movie that I don't know where to start. I'll just mention a few:<br /><br />1. Brett Ratner stinks as a director<br /><br />2. Special effects, no matter how cool, are never a substitute for a strong plot and strong dialogue (unless you're just a mindless consumer of action flicks)<br /><br />3. Magneto, played by Ian McKellan, wears his helmet almost the entire second half of the movie. If you recall, he wore this helmet to stop the thoughts of Xavier from infiltrating and influencing his mind. Why, then, did Magneto continue to wear his helmet after Xavier was annihilated?<br /><br />4. If Xavier was going to die, he deserved a better send off than having his protege having a cosmic tantrum and destroying him<br /><br />5. Why is Logan/Wolverine smiling up at the sky, school campus awash in sunshine and colorful flowers, when he's lost his father figure and had to kill the woman he loves--in effect losing her TWICE?<br /><br />6. Bobby (Ice Boy) begins to get cozy with the Girl Who Can Walk Through Walls. There is little interaction between he and Rogue (poor Anna Paquin hardly gets any air time!)--and Rogue knows Bobby is cozy with the other chick. Yet, she takes the cure to rid her of her mutant powers so she can touch/kiss Bobby? Maybe--but GEEZ. Weren't enough mutants already killed or neutralized?!<br /><br />So we have Mystique neutralized (she's a mere human), as is Magneto and Rogue. Xavier is dead, as is Jean Grey and Cyclops. Storm is in charge of the school, Wolverine is hunky dory with the way everything has turned out, and the mutants and humans are now united--living happily ever after.<br /><br />For crying out loud!!<br /><br />The only good thing about this movie was the special effects and some cool mutants like \\"Tin Man\\" (can't remember his real name), the blue fur guy, Juggernaut (very cool!), Angel Boy (also cool) and a kid who sprouts spikes.<br /><br />However, that's not enough to save this movie. We were so disgusted that I'm going to list this movie on Amazon for sale right after I write this review. (We didn't even want to explore the extras or alternative endings!)<br /><br />What a waste of EXCELLENT acting talent. (That is, Ian McKellan, Patrick Stewart, Hugh Jackman, and AnnaPaquin.)<br /><br />Whoever agreed to hand this debacle over to Brett Ratner should be excommunicated from Hollywood--as should Ratner himself and whoever wrote this lacklaster script.<br /><br />What a way to sink an incredible, exciting movie franchise!ever wrote this lacklaster script.     What a way to sink an incredible, exciting movie franchise!
B0000029LG|5.0|Michael Jackson's downfall came very close on to the downfall of a hopeful pop culture. Most know the story all too well. At last the press had something on MJ. He was accused of being a child molester in an extortion attempt. This all mingled with an aggressive alternative rock writer/critics culture who wanted to topple anything that culturally represented the previous decade? And Mike's life,already tenuous would be spinning out of control. Of course we know now the man was physically suffering from a synergistic combination of Vitiligo,Lupus and his burns incurred shooting the 1984 Pepsi commercial. This was a man who,in addition of being accused of child abuse,was now addicted to pain killers. The years 1993 to this point marked the period when Mike went from being famous to infamous,from a trusted musical icon and children's rights activist to a suspected villain. The editorial review right here on Amazon.com by Steven Mirkin said it all: Michael Jackson now represented everything a newer youth culture,who were torn in terms of getting involved in helping society,were willing to reject both personally and culturally. At the same time,a strange cult of personality surrounding him was continuing to grow. Taking two years to finish,this album was packaged as a double album with his greatest hits from [[ASIN:B00005QGAT Off the Wall]] through [[ASIN:B00005QGAV Dangerous]]-almost as if this should be a frame of reference to what he would offer next. Production wise,Mike turned to Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis,famous for making his sister Janet a star,to help out with many of the songs on this album. Personally? This is probably an album I anticipated more than any other in my entire life. Almost to the point where even I thought I was building up to a disappointment. Luckily that didn't happen. Still it didn't stop me from finding this content surprising to a very high level.<br /><br />  \\"Scream\\" opens the album with...a chaotic industrial funk/rock mix full of static,feedback and genuine sampled screaming as he and his sister Janet sing together for the whole system \\"that sucks\\" to \\"stop pressuring me\\". \\"They Don't Care About Us\\",probably better known for its controversial self effacing \\"jew me,sue me\\" lyric (though MJ was obviously not Jewish) is a pounding,Afrofuturist uptempo march where Mike sings of being \\"tired of being a victim of hate and shame\\" and that \\"If Martin Luther (King?) was living,he wouldn't let this be\\". So Mike demonstrates that he is deeply in touch with the fact racism is only hidden just under the surface,and not dead,in America. \\"This Time Around\\",\\"Tabloid Junkie\\" and \\"2 Bad\\" again utilize Mike's beat boxing as a percussion element,with guest rappers Shaquille O'Neal and such making cameos,to find MJ both musically and lyrically taking on a stronger hip-hop/funk stance-even including some profanity that made this Mike's first and only album to earn a \\"Tipper Sticker\\". His focus on these songs range from taking defending his honor,place in the media and female fans trying to place a wedge between him and than wife Lisa Marie Presley. \\"Stranger In Moscow\\" is a stripped down,orchestral modern day folk/rock style production with a bluesy,Bill Withers type melody where Michael sings of near total alienation by and from the rest of the world-asking \\"how does it when feel when your alone and your cold inside?\\".  \\"Earth Song\\" is a hugely orchestrated gospel number-not for a god but for the environmental damage humanity was doing to the planet. One of the oddest turns to me was a song called \\"D.S\\". Obviously meant to be wittily called \\"TS\\",the riff heavy,guitar fueled funk/rocker with Slash has a chorus that clearly says \\"Tom Sneddon is a cold man\\",yet the lyrics print \\"Dom Sheldon\\".<br /><br />  \\"Money\\" is a lean,mean funk number with a heavy bass line. Excellent hip-hop oriented number with a wonderfully sung chorus. But Mike rapping the refrains of the song in his trademark high whisper is a bit of a musical fail-yes, but it does perhaps express his trepidation at embracing rap/hip-hop so strongly. \\"Come Together\\" is a pretty straight,sleek cover of the Beatles hit which came from 1988's [[ASIN:B0033TJATW Moonwalker]]. \\"You Are Not Alone\\" is probably the best known hit from this album,and perhaps its most life affirming-pointing to loneliness always having some resolution with a typically vital R.Kelly funky slow groove production and an anthemic gospel chorus. \\"Childhood\\" is a very Broadway style,orchestrally rich ballad made as a theme to [[ASIN:B001QVT1NE Free Willy 2]]-with Mike spilling pouring his heart out for people to love him before they judge him,since he's only compensating for a childhood he now desperately needs to revisit for solace. With its mixture of voice samples of people quoting random dates and famous historical quotes from MLK,FDR,etc the title song is both hand clap power gospel and a pounding,beat heavy hip-hop funk on the refrains. So it gets two seemingly disparate worlds of music and shows where they connect up-all while asking for young people not to give up on learning from the past.  \\"Little Susie\\" is one of the most emotionally harrowing song I've heard from MJ-perhaps anyone. Musically performed in the manner of a musical theater-type renaissance madrigal,it tells the story of an abandoned child who dies after years of neglect by those around her. Something tells me Mike tearing up while singing \\"she knew no one cared\\" was not the least bit intended. I teared up a little in the end. \\"Smile\\" is a well interpreted version of Charlie Chaplin (a known hero of MJ's)...well until Mike's unusually weak whistling at the end.<br /><br />  Considering the complete breakdown,in terms of his psyche and reputation just preceding this albums release? I half expected the performances on this album to be mediocre at best. While I still question the almost megalomaniacal elements of the promotion of this album (including its infamous theatrical trailer)? This album really does an excellent job instrumentally extending on the themes he'd begun to explore on his previous album. The Mike's-beatboxing-as-percussion is still in place. As his that rougher,deeper and more growling vocal style that I love so much from him during his early/mid 90's period. Also Jam & Lewis help Mike transition from the manically uptempo new jack swing sound into the slower,and therefore somewhat funkier sounds of the hip-hop/soul sound just coming onto the scene at this time. There are some points were Mike's performance does falter a bit-particularly when he directly embraces rapping or his more whispery tones get in the way. But that may have been good for Mike at this point. Presented as a worshipful stone statue on the front cover? That emphasizes the irony of these performance jitters that the \\"King Of Pop\\" was not at all infallible. And was in fact all too human. Lyrically this album is not the paranoid ranting one might expect,and others make it out to be. Quite the contrary, Mike continually brings in the classic soul concept of mingling the secular with the spiritual throughout this album-speaking for example of yellow journalists \\"selling their souls to the devil\\" for money,while also adding a surprisingly strong racial component to the L.A PD's smear campaign against him. So along with fellow Motown alumni Marvin Gaye's [[ASIN:B000001AKC Here My Dear]] and Stevie Wonder's [[ASIN:B00004S367 Music of My Mind]],this album gives us a window into MJ's divided soul at the time. And it reveals itself as a musically enriched and personally telling work that could very well be his masterpiece of tension and release.ail-yes, but it does perhaps express his trepidation at embracing rap/hip-hop so strongly. \\"Come Together\\" is a pretty straight,sleek cover of the Beatles hit which came from 1988's [[ASIN:B0033TJATW Moonwalker]]. \\"You Are Not Alone\\" is probably the best known hit from this album,and perhaps its most life affirming-pointing to loneliness always having some resolution with a typically vital R.Kelly funky slow groove production and an anthemic gospel chorus. \\"Childhood\\" is a very Broadway style,orchestrally rich ballad made as a theme to [[ASIN:B001QVT1NE Free Willy 2]]-with Mike spilling pouring his heart out for people to love him before they judge him,since he's only compensating for a childhood he now desperately needs to revisit for solace. Also Jam & Lewis help Mike transition from the manically uptempo new jack swing sound into the slower,and therefore somewhat funkier sounds of the hip-hop/soul sound just coming onto the scene at this time. But that may have been good for Mike at this point. Presented as a worshipful stone statue on the front cover? That emphasizes the irony of these performance jitters that the \\"King Of Pop\\" was not at all infallible. And was in fact all too human. Lyrically this album is not the paranoid ranting one might expect,and others make it out to be. Quite the contrary, Mike continually brings in the classic soul concept of mingling the secular with the spiritual throughout this album-speaking for example of yellow journalists \\"selling their souls to the devil\\" for money,while also adding a surprisingly strong racial component to the L.A PD's smear campaign against him. So along with fellow Motown alumni Marvin Gaye's [[ASIN:B000001AKC Here My Dear]] and Stevie Wonder's [[ASIN:B00004S367 Music of My Mind]],this album gives us a window into MJ's divided soul at the time. And it reveals itself as a musically enriched and personally telling work that could very well be his masterpiece of tension and release.
B000GUJZ4G|5.0|Everything about Point Break may seem ludicrous upon first glance, but thanks to having a more than competent director behind the camera (Kathryn Bigelow who helmed Near Dark, Strange Days, and K-19: The Widowmaker) and surprisingly great performances from Patrick Swayze, Keanu Reeves, and Gary Busey. The story revolves around special agent Johnny Utah (Reeves) and his veteran partner (Busey) on the trail of a group of bank robbers who wear masks of ex-presidents. Soon enough, Reeves infiltrates a group of surfers (led by Swayze) who turn out to be linked to the robbers. The performances are great, especially Swayze who gives one of his last high profile film performances before his career began to decline. The fantasticly shot skydiving and surfing sequences are worth the price of admission alone, and Bigelow manages to nicely orchestrate some great action scenes. Although it didn't fare very well at the box office, to this day Point Break continues to garner a cult following thanks to home video and television. There's plenty of familiar faces abound as well, including Lori Petty, as well as smaller roles from John C. McGinley, Tom Sizemore, Lee Tergesen (better known as Beecher from HBO's Oz), and Red Hot Chili Peppers frontman Anthony Kiedis.
0375505091|5.0|Even if you aren't into photography, you can certainly appreciate the quality, professionalism and beauty of Annie's work.  She's one of the most trusted photographers around and she's been in the business for so long doing amazing work.  This book is delightful to look at. <br />She actually studied to become a painter, but instead she's created works of art with her camera.  This new collection is a personal retrospective and an amazing collection of great photography.  Inside are the trademark celebrity photos, landscapes and also for the first time, some personal family photos (the births of her children).  There are also pictures of her best friend and partner, Susan, while healthy and while dying.   <br />There is an incredible mix of stunning pictures in here and it's a gorgeous book to look at, to give as a gift, buy for yourself or to let your friends look through it if you leave it on your coffee table.  There is something for everyone in here and I highly, highly recommend it.

0743298020|5.0|An amazing and captivating story!  Setterfield does more than simply tell you a story.  Her writing brings you into the heart of the tale and envelopes you.  Instantly you are drawn into the mystery of why a famous and enigmatic writer would want a virtual no one to write her biography.  The first letter we read of Vida Winters instantly draws you into the story.   <br /> <br />Once the story of her family begins, it is extremely compelling. 0783225849|5.0|`Psycho' is probably one of the most definitive films of cinema, not just horror but of pure American cinema.  The acting, the direction, the plot, script...everything is utterly brilliant and can compare with today's standards and still stand out as truly inspired film.  Alfred Hitchcock was probably the smartest movie-maker of his generation, and maybe even ours, for he knew how to get what he wanted with very little, to make the most of what he had and he always delivered something smart, edgy and ahead of it's time. <br /> <br />`Psycho', of course, is no exception.  Probably his most popular film, and arguably his best, `Psycho' has been the inspiration for countless rip-offs, sequels and a remake, none of which have even come close to the power of the original.  Psycho itself was inspired by the real life account of serial killer Ed Gein, and man brutally abused by his mother into believing that women were evil.  Ed Gein himself has been the inspiration for many films including `The Texas Chain Saw Massacre' and `The Silence of the Lambs', both of which fall in the line of `Psycho' as cinematic landmarks, but arguably `Psycho' was and is the most important. <br /> <br />Unbeknownst to anyone who has seen this film post its original release, Hitchcock really wove a twisted web.  You see, everyone who's heard of the film after it was released has heard that it's about a crazy momma's boy who kills a woman in the shower, but knowing the story does a somewhat disservice to Hitchcock for he really went all out to weave a tangled web of mystery as to the who's and why's.  Regardless though, everything about this film is extraordinary and deserving of praise.  Of particular note is the excellent acting on the part of the entire cast, but of course Anthony Perkins and Janet Leigh (who received a well deserved Oscar nomination) are particular standouts. <br /> <br />I'm guessing I don't really need to explain the plot, but for the sake of discussion I will.  The moviestarts by giving us some back story on our famous victim, Marion Crane (Leigh) who is involved with Sam Loomis (John Gavin) but because of his impending divorce they have no means to make it, that is until she gets her hands on $40,000.  Of course it's stolen money and the man she stole it from is all but a little unhappy.  She flees the city and stops at off the road motel run by Norman Bates (Anthony Perkins) who lives with his overbearing (oh yeah, and dead) mother.  After Marion is murdered (the classic shower scene) her sister Lila (Vera Miles) and Sam send a detective to find her (they just assume she's missing, run off with the money and all) but what they find is a crazy house of horrors. <br /> <br />`Psycho', above all else, succeeds in creating the perfect mood for a film of this nature, giving us enough air of gloom and eerie atmosphere to breathe life to this brilliant film.  Horror movies of today may try, but I highly doubt any film will really come close to what Hitchcock created with `Psycho'.  This film proves, beyond a shadow of a doubt, that it's that silent sinister feeling that creates real, pure and raw terror, not blood gore and mayhem.
B000HVHM5S|5.0|This movie was trashed by the mainstream media critics uncluding the NY Times, but the people liked the movie. It was ranked 3rd by the NY Times readers.
B000009DUY|4.0|Does anyone know the name of the singer or title of the song that was playing on the record player just before the last battle?  The one that Upham had to translate?
B00005JPAD|5.0|The Departed is, in short, a stunning achievement from director Martin Scorsese, who gleefully returns to the hard-hitting gangster genre that made him famous. Joining him in his return is one of the better casts you'll likely find in one movie, and all of these elements combined make this one a must see. <br />    <br />   I don't usually give a plot description because anyone who has read this far down the page probably already knows as much or more than they wanted without actually seeing the film. To put it simply, Jack Nicholson plays the only clearly definable bad-guy in the film. Everyone else is morally iffy at best. This is definitely not a movie for those seeking characters to admire or root for, although it's so involving and played so well that you'll likely find yourself rooting for just about everyone regardless. <br />    <br />   The performances in this film make this film, period. Jack Nicholson is spectacular as only Jack can be. He's basically here to remind the audience what a commanding and terrific actor he is, especially as a villain. He's equally terrifying and hilarious and, as always, it seems so effortless. Matt Damon also continues to prove his chops in a tricky role of dual personalities and dual motives. He brings across both his Good Will Hunting charm and his Jason Bourne brooding to great effect. His role is complex, to say the least, and you don't really know his true nature until the climax.  <br />    <br />   The real star of this show, however, turns out to be Leonardo DiCaprio.  His outstanding performance is a revelation of his true talent, and it's safe to say that I was absolutely blown away by it. He perfectly blends a tough guy (and he is tough) with a regular guy that wants no part of all of that ugliness. He is completely desperate throughout, both in his current situation caught torn between cops and gangsters, as well as his long-time desire to rid himself of his family's shameful legacy. DiCaprio makes you believeall of this from beginning to end, and if any acting awards are handed out for this film, they should go to Leo (sorry Jack)! <br />    <br />   The Departed also benefits from an unusually stellar supporting cast. Mark Wahlberg, Martin Sheen and Alec Baldwin could easily headline their own film, but they all shine as role players in this one. Relative newcomer Vera Farmiga holds her own pretty well as the only female, which is pretty impressive considering that alone, not to mention the quality and reputation of the all-male cast she has to contend with. <br />    <br />   This movie is definitely not for children or the squeamish. It's violent, gritty, brutal, sexually charged, and almost every other word is four-letters. This is easily distinguishable as a Scorsese picture and is for mature adults that can enjoy this sort of thing and not take it too seriously. That said, any takers will be pleasantly surprised and thoroughly entertained.  <br />    <br />   The Departed is definitely not an indie movie and never feels like one. This is pure old-fashioned Hollywood in the best tradition. Yeah, yeah, I know what you're thinking: Hollywood is anything but consistent & these days rarely of any real quality. Granted, but every once in a while a movie like this is made and reminds us that when the stars align in the right way, it is worth the price of admission and then some.
B000E1ZBGS|5.0|I have always looked forward to movies interpreting Jane Austen's classic novels. When I learned that there might be a new P & P movie, I wonder how can this movie provide a new perspective to the acclaimed BBC production which starred an excellent and competent cast led by Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle. But here comes Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFayden, both goodlooking actors who provided the conflict, the feelings unspoken but sizzling through the screen, the fiery, passionate dialogue and the blissful happy ending that two people in love deserve so much. Excellent movie. More excellent script. Most excellent cast!
B000FL7CAK|2.0|I was totally looking forward to watching the second season of Veronica Mars but it turned out to be a huge disappointment. I think you really need to watch it twice to understand most of what's going on because the writing doesn't direct your attention to a lot of the things that you're supposed to take note of that become relevent later on. It's more immediately concerned with having Veronica always following dead-end leads to keep the mystery going, so by the time she actually gets on the right track you don't know what pieces of information are still relevent. Like in episode 1 when Veronica asks her dad to look up the shareholders of Boatloads Of Fun Corp, I had no idea where she got that name from or why she thought they were involved. Watching it a second time I realised that one of the athletes who was framed for drug use mentioned earlier to Veronica that the company was sueing her parents, but it didn't register as a pertinent piece of information because at the time there didn't seem to be any reason to think they were a suspect.   There are also moments of lazy writing that has characters behavior serving to progress a plot point without having any internal logic. Like the part in episode 1 where the cop shows up at Veronica's door to arrest Logan like he knows Logan is there and Veronica is harbouring him. If the cop thinks Logan is guilty of murder why would he assume Logan told Veronica anything about what happened on the bridge, and why would he assume Logan would more likely be at Veronica's than have just left town or even the country?  Then there's the ipod switch in episode 3. Seemingly Veronica had the ipod she gave Kendall rigged to take pictures, but there's so much there that goes unexplained, like how Kendall wouldn't have immediately realised the music on the ipod wasn't hers and chased Veronica down to get hers back before she even left the gym, or why Kendall would have the ipod out in the open all day for it to take all those pictures when she was meeting with people, rather than putting it in a bag or her pocket or something.   Then there's some things that just never make sense, like in episode 5 the sheriff is trying to blackmail Jackie's dad into buying 1000 tickets to an annual fundraiser. Apprently Terrence has gambling debts, but how exactly the sheriff or cop was using this against him remains unclear. It seems like the sheriff was threatening to tell his creditors his wherabouts, but if Terrence was hiding out from his creditors in Neptune why would he make a public appearance at the baseball stadium to talk to the students? And didn't his creditor later turn out to be the owner of a local casino? So if his debts were local anyway obviously he wasn't hiding out in Neptune. Maybe the cop was threatening to arrest him for illegal gambling, but if that was that case shouldn't the cop have shown what evidence he had?   The characters even seem duller this time around. Veronica's Buffyesque sarcastic lines are still in effect, but in this season she's more conservatively righteous than the first season where her moral compass seemed to allow her more freedom to get the job done. Weevil looks about 30 and the kid who plays Wallace is about the least charismatic actor to ever disgrace tv screens.   If you have an explanation for any of the things I've said don't make sense, post it.
B0006IINSW|5.0|This album is a real find. It's beautifully crafted and really well played. 0156030322|4.0|Driver drives, that's all he does. He doesn't want details. Just tell him where to be and when to be there. That's all.<br /><br />By day, he's one of Hollywood's best stunt drivers. By night, he's one of the underworld's best getaway drivers. Corruption and scandal litters both industries, but he stays out of it. He's survived unscathed because he only drives and he doesn't want details. His reputation has a long reach. He has become a hot commodity in both professions because all he does is drive... until he gets double-crossed, and then his business mantra changes.<br /><br />It was a simple job. Easy money. But things turned south quickly, and soon Driver finds himself bleeding in a run-down motel room surrounded by three dead bodies and straining to listen for the distant sounds of sirens. He knows who's responsible and he has nothing to lose.<br /><br />The plot flows through a series of flashbacks building the character known as Driver. Raised in a foster home, he is the product of simple self-preservation and the evolution of childhood dreams into day-to-day survival. Driver's past is filled with images of a broken mother and a lost chance at love, interspersed with memories of an underground surgeon who could challenge the Mayo Clinic's best and a mentor who gave him his first big break. As the character takes form, the story takes hold. The suspense is as thick as Driver's outer shell and the action is as fast and heavy as his right foot.<br /><br />In the end, Driver - a once nomadic kid who loved cars - becomes part of modern American folklore, at least to those who love to drive.<br /><br />It's a short novel but flows more like a long short story and it's quite entertaining in an urban legend kind of way, and Driver is a character who commands fascination. The recurring flashbacks chop up the storyline and it may take more than one read-through to fully appreciate the writer's style and the sequence of events, but overall this one is a winner.<br /><br />Reviewed on behalf of MyShelf.com<br /> <br />Reviewed on behalf of MyShelf.com
B0001E5TSS|5.0|Please note that this review is for the PAL rather than the NTSC version of the film.<br /><br />Ironically, after creating this cinematic masterpiece, Welles, now the outcast boy wonder director of Hollywood at the ripe old age of 26, spent the next half century with his hand out trying to fund similarly visionary films that never got made, although he continued to be popular as an actor. Everyone praised his work as that of a great genius but no one would give him more work, after Citizen Kane was hailed as a masterpiece but still lost $150,000. And no investor was willing to put up money for a brilliant but eccentric genius no matter how gifted who couldn't pull in the receipts at the box office--essentially no different from what happens today.<br /><br />Welles's predicament reminded me of the great Spencer Tracy at the end of his career, who said the same thing. Prior to his being cast in \\"Guess Who's Coming to Dinner,\\" no one would insure him for the movie due to his heart condition, so he and Katherine bought the insurance themselves, according to the story. He made the same comment about everyone praising his work but no one being willing to hire him.<br /><br />This film resembles more a 19th century late romantic symphony or a work of jaded Impressionism than a typical American film. It melds dramatic camera angles and cinematography, world weary, fin de siecle dialog, a brooding and almost nihilistic atmosphere, and a non-chronological timeline to create what for the time was a revolutionary film. In one scene in the film, where the enraged Welles as Hearst is trashing his study, scattering books and various objects everywhere, he said afterwords, \\"By God, I felt it, I really felt it.\\" Overall, Welles's signature work of genius and one of the most influential movies of all time.
B00005JPAM|5.0|Helen Mirren is at the center of Stephen Frears' \\"The Queen,\\" a fictionalized film based on real events that took place in 1997.  Mirren physically and psychologically inhabits the role of HRH Elizabeth II, a monarch who never sought the heavy responsibilities that came with the crown, but who, for more than four decades, performed her role with dignity.<br /><br />The film's main theme is the manner in which the royals reacted to the tragic death of Princess Diana.  Newly elected Prime Minister Tony Blair, a \\"modernist,\\" believed that Diana should be mourned publicly and that flags should be flown in royal residences at half-staff.  In addition, he urged Elizabeth to make some sort of public statement to the British people, who criticized the Queen for grieving privately on her estate in Scotland.  How shocked Elizabeth was when she learned that some members of the press and public blamed her for Diana's unhappiness and subsequent death!  In one scene, a bewildered Elizabeth murmurs, \\"It's a bad dream.\\"  On another occasion, she expresses her chagrin at the turn events have taken:  \\"There's been a change--a shift in values.\\"  She cannot understand why, for the first time, members of the royal family should be expected to show their feelings in public.<br /><br />Miss Mirren's stellar performance overshadows everyone else's in the cast, although James Cromwell is effective as a bombastic and insensitive Prince Philip and Michael Sheen does nice work as a callow Tony Blair who gradually grows into his new job as Prime Minister of England.  Although he is at first put off by Elizabeth's stiffness and formality, Blair later comes to admire her devotion to duty.  Alex Jennings, who does not physically resemble Prince Charles, plays the Prince as a compassionate man who, although he divorced Diana, still respected her devotion to William and Harry. Sylvia Syms plays the Queen Mum as a cartoonish matriarch who says whatever pops into her head.<br /><br />Frears uses archival footage of Diana and the hordes who paid tribute to her memory to bring back the emotionally charged atmosphere of those dark days.  The director contrasts these crowd scenes with the eerily remote and silent castle to which Elizabeth and her family retreat following the death of the \\"People's Princess.\\"  Was Elizabeth truly as uncaring and cold as she appeared to many members of the press and public?  Did the royals mistreat Diana and somehow cause her to act recklessly?  There are no easy answers to these questions, nor does Frears take a clear position on these issues.  \\"The Queen\\" is worth seeing for its satirical and incisive look at a particular time in British history when a venerated institution, the British monarchy, came under fire after the royal family failed to meet a challenge that they never expected to face--to be the mourners-in-chief for a woman whom they personally disliked but who was cherished by the entire world.nd the hordes who paid tribute to her memory to bring back the emotionally charged atmosphere of those dark days. Did the royals mistreat Diana and somehow cause her to act recklessly? 006056251X|5.0|I have been a tried and true Kleypas fan since her first book Where Passion Leads in 1987.  She only kept getting better and all her books have been exceptional - I must admit that I was a bit disappointed with The Wallflower Quartet as the stories in this series were slow and not as good as her other works.  It is difficult to find a writer that maintains consistency in the quality of their writing and Lisa Kleypas has done that throughout the years - if you've just started to read her - try to get your hands on every one of her books - they are all gems.   <br /> <br />Okay - so I persevered and I am so glad that I did - the Devil in the Winter proved itself and it is by far the best in the Wallflower installment in the series.  Lisa's old writing style is back.   <br /> <br />Ivie - Evangeline - is the most flawed of all the wallflowers.  She is painfully shy, stammers and has almost been kept a virtual prisoner by her abusive family - keeping her from seeing her father who is dying and is the owner of a notorious Gaming club in London.   <br /> <br />Sebastian, the hero in the book (but somewhat villain in the last one!) gets propositioned by Ivie for a marriage of convenience - (who would have thought that such a stammering and shy young woman would have the courage to enter the \\"lion's\\" den and actually proposition him on a marriage of convenience!).  After their elopement to get married, as Ivie's family is hot on her heels, he spends time getting to know her, nurturing Ivie and giving her the care and attention that has been lacking from her horribly controlling family.   The storyline grabs you from the start and it keeps you turning the pages with the infamous sensuality and tenderness that is so much a part of all of Kleypas' stories.  The passion leaped out of the pages and I couldn't put the book down - neither will you.  <br /> <br />Oh, on a side note - another writer similar to Kleypas is Gaelen Foley - her books are excellent and her manner of writing very similar to Kleypas.   <br />

B000GY729M|5.0|I want to write a review of Sam's Town and not compare it to Hot Fuss. From their humble beginning at playing various gay clubs in Vegas to their almost overnight success of Hot Fuss; Sam's Town is the perfect album at this time to be put out with strong hooks, anthem-memorable choruses, and intense energy.  The first 8 tracks of Sam's Town are flawless.  From the big pre-chorus of Sam's Town, to the catchy opening riff in the current single \\"When You Were Young, to the intriguing lyrics of \\"Uncle Johnny\\"  (there's a big dealer in Vegas named Johnny, I wonder if Brandon wrote this with anyone in mind??) the songs take a life on their own. I would have given the album \\"5 axes to the head\\" but the last 3 songs, \\"My List\\" \\"The River Runs Wild\\" and \\"Why Do I keep Counting\\" seem like \\"throw-away\\" keeping this from being one of the best records in the past 20 years as Brandon Flowers would claim.  This is a mature album done my musicians that are slowly perfecting their craft.  Keuning has developed some wonderful tone on his guitar, and his rifts are right in the pocket along with Vannucci's drumming.  Put in the \\"out of the box\\" bass lines with some \\"heavy thump\\" by Stroemer (originally a guitarst with a little band called The Negative Ponies) and you can tell these guys are here to play and the 2 years of touring off Hot Fuss has improved their chops.  Now if they can only get the 3rd album to be the best in 20 years then they will be a direct hit.

B00005JPAD|5.0|Jack Nicholson as \\"Frank Costello\\" goes way over the top in this one (think THE SHINING & WITCHES OF EASTWICK & BATMAN) but then that just might be the thing that makes this film succeed so well.<br /><br />Nicholson is garnering a lot of attention for this role. In recent years it seems like Jack has just been lending his talents out to quirky romantic comedies until something better comes along. Well, The Departed is that something better. Jack just seems so thrilled to be in this movie that he can't stand or sit still. I've never seen a Jack Nicholson role where Jack felt such a compulsive need to be inventive. And it is an exciting thing to see. With a film like this you need a strong charismatic center and there's no one on the planet with more charisma than Jack. You could argue that with a slightly less mannered \\"performance\\" Jack would have drawn more attention to the character that he was playing instead of attention to himself as an actor capable of doing, and getting away with doing, anything that he wants. But then maybe this is exactly the kind of performance that is needed to make the all-too-familiar goodfella look new and interesting again. I'm wavering with my estimation of Jack's performance but that is maybe what a unique rendering of an all too familiar character makes you do: re-assess why the mobster is such a fascinating film type. This new take on a familiar character challenges the stereotype of what a mob guy can be.  In this film a mob guy can be an artist (both con and graphic), a father, jokester, and most controversial of all, a guy with friends and complex international contacts and business interests in all kinds of places. Its not just Jack's performance that is new but the character itself as written by screenwriter William Monahan (who in turn is not starting from scratch but re-imagining a character originally created by Alan Mak and Felix Chong; who co-wrote the script for \\"Internal Affairs\\") is something we just haven't seen before.<br /><br />[Exactly who deserves credit for the original elements of this film is a matter generating some debate. It should be noted that many Asian film makers see Scorcese as a huge influence. Certainly with The Departed Scorcese is borrowing a story from those who have borrowed from him, but like any great film maker he makes what he borrows his own. This transcultural borrowing has always existed in all art forms and actually benefits all cultures and allows us to compare how different stories work differently in different cultural contexts. I would recommend seeing both Internal Affairs & The Departed and comparing how the same characters and plot lines can mean very different things in different cultures. This kind of comparitive viewing can actually be very interesting, not to mention commensurate to a greater understanding of our own culture as well as a greater understanding of other cultures, including non-western ones.]<br /><br />DiCaprio (who I did not think was quite right in either GANGS OF NEW YORK or THE AVIATOR) does seem to suit this film's purposes more than he did the former two Scorcese projects. Although, DiCaprio is not an actor who gives you a fully imagined character (not in the way DeNiro does) he is good at playing internally conflicted characters. What DiCaprio does well is convey a sense of unease with himself and thats just what he's supposed to do. His \\"Billy Costigan\\" is a brainy kid from South Boston who attends the police academy in the hopes of becoming a cop and redeeming the family name (he comes from a long line of mobsters). But his superiors decide that with his family being what it is they cannot trust him and that he'll never be a cop in South Boston. They do give him one option: use your mob pedigree to go undercover for us and infiltrate Frank Costello's bunch of goodfellas. Leo's character accepts this duty only because he has no other choice but he never likes the idea of having to pretend to be the very kind of character that he is trying not to be. Throughout the film Billy Costigan fights a psychic duel with himself as he questions what he is truly made of and where his loyalties really lie and this is only exacerbated by the fact that he never really knows who he can rely on in the department and who he can really trust.  DiCaprio's moments with Nicholson are the stuff of movie legend; these kinds of moments are the reason you still get exicted about movies, and this exciting pairing keeps you on the edge of your seat. Jack plays his role less like a mobster (his own loyalties to crew and comrades are questionable at best) than like a megalomaniac psychotic bent on expanding his prodigious ego into new markets; his real motive seems to be having the ability to shape and govern his own life and the lives of those around him and, ultimately, he sees himself as a kind of untouchable lord of the criminal underworld. A good number of Stones songs on the soundtrack seem to hint toward a correlation between Jack Nicholson and Jumpin'Jack Flash himself. He's an utterly corrupt manipulator who loves molding the new kids on the block in his own image and DiCaprio and Damon are just two of his acolyte/proteges, or so he thinks (and theres the rub). Jack indulges himself in scene after scene but DiCaprio (as an actor and as Billy Costigan) never flinches. If DiCaprio does find himself being handed the statue on Oscar night its, in part, because Nicholson's performance makes his own look like a study in stoic restraint. Though the two performances are entirely different they compliment each other brilliantly.<br /><br />Matt Damon is equally good as \\"Colin Sullivan\\" but its a thankless role as he's the guy everyone is allowed, even encouraged, to hate. While DiCaprio is a mole in Frank Costello's crew working for the state, Damon plays DiCaprio's opposite number as a mole in the police department working for Frank Costello. So while DiCaprio is set on catching Nicholson, Damon is set on protecting him. Eventually they each realize that their own cover may be blown by the other mole and survival for each depends on who sniffs who out first. And though these two interact mainly via cellphone as they hunt the true identity of the man that is hunting them their personal motives for doing what they do does provide audience members with an interesting compare & contrast scenario. Both kids are from the same neighborhood and both are very gifted but each took a decidedly different turn at a key point in their childhoods. The larger question being asked by Scorcese is to what extent we are each a product of our environments and to what extent we are able to exert some amount of control over our lives but you may not have time to address the larger implications of these questions once the bullets begin to fly.<br /><br />Another performance that is creating a lot of buzz is Vera Farmiga's portrayal of the police psychologist who ends up dating both Sullivan and Costigan. At first she seems like she is just there to draw derisive laughs from both of these tough South Boston natives for being a naive ivy-leaguer attempting to be a do-gooder in a hard as nails precinct. But then we realize that she is actually there to allow us a glimpse of the  vulnerable side of these two moles.  In other words she's there to give us a glimpse of these two guys with their gaurds down. And its in her presence that we learn what each guy is really made of. Its not a large role nor is it even a flashy one as she is there mainly to react to the two guys. But she does a solid job with the role and gives her character a credibility and complexity that is as unusual as it is unexpected. Like everyone else in this film \\"Madolyn\\" is not exactly certain what she is made of either.<br /><br />This is a great cast no doubt and Scorcese succeeds in getting inventive and entertaining performances from his actors. Its obvious that Scorcese is encouraging his actors to do something original with their parts so that this mob movie will be distinct from others (and Scorcese has plenty of imitators so it is paramount that he do something original with the genre). Having a half dozen eccentrics in one film may seem like overload but no one does anything so over the top that it compromises the overall integrity of the film. Though its chock full of stars and performances (any one of which would have stolen the show in any other film) this still feels like a piece of collaborative team acting. And that is yet another of this films great achievements.<br /><br />This is a surefire hit. Can't wait to see it again.ally they each realize that their own cover may be blown by the other mole and survival for each depends on who sniffs who out first. And though these two interact mainly via cellphone as they hunt the true identity of the man that is hunting them their personal motives for doing what they do does provide audience members with an interesting compare & contrast scenario. Both kids are from the same neighborhood and both are very gifted but each took a decidedly different turn at a key point in their childhoods. The larger question being asked by Scorcese is to what extent we are each a product of our environments and to what extent we are able to exert some amount of control over our lives but you may not have time to address the larger implications of these questions once the bullets begin to fly.         Another performance that is creating a lot of buzz is Vera Farmiga's portrayal of the police psychologist who ends up dating both Sullivan and Costigan. At first she seems like she is just there to draw derisive laughs from both of these tough South Boston natives for being a naive ivy-leaguer attempting to be a do-gooder in a hard as nails precinct. But then we realize that she is actually there to allow us a glimpse of the  vulnerable side of these two moles.  In other words she's there to give us a glimpse of these two guys with their gaurds down. And its in her presence that we learn what each guy is really made of. Its not a large role nor is it even a flashy one as she is there mainly to react to the two guys. But she does a solid job with the role and gives her character a credibility and complexity that is as unusual as it is unexpected. Like everyone else in this film \\"Madolyn\\" is not exactly certain what she is made of either.      This is a great cast no doubt and Scorcese succeeds in getting inventive and entertaining performances from his actors. Its obvious that Scorcese is encouraging his actors to do something original with their parts so that thismob movie will be distinct from others (and Scorcese has plenty of imitators so it is paramount that he do something original with the genre). Having a half dozen eccentrics in one film may seem like overload but no one does anything so over the top that it compromises the overall integrity of the film. Though its chock full of stars and performances (any one of which would have stolen the show in any other film) this still feels like a piece of collaborative team acting. And that is yet another of this films great achievements.       This is a surefire hit. Can't wait to see it again.

B00003CX8V|5.0|This film was so close to being awesome and yet I didn't quite like the ending as much as I could have. For the entire film the main character is taken advantage of, used, stood up and beaten down time and time again. And yet at the end of the movie, somehow his love interest sees the error of her ways and comes running back to him. I completely disapprove of that. If this were real life, after she had drained every drop of anything good she could possibly get from him, she would come back and steal his kidney(s) and then run off with his boss to live unhappily for the rest of her life and wonder why she is so unhappy. That is what would happen if this were real life.<br /><br />That being said, I did like this movie. Then there is Baxter who falls in love with a girl that stands him up and treats him, by all accounts, very poorly; yet he can't help but fall in love with her. These are all themes that rings as true today as I am sure they did back in 1960.hey did back in 1960.

I still have to give it a 4 out of 5 though because it has a quality all its own. Just not what I expected.
B00005V9IJ|5.0|This is a very moving film of one man's determination to stay alive while alone on a desert island after a plane crash. I can't imagine being in the situation that Chuck was in without ever once looking to the Lord for help.    But even so, something stirred inside me as I was watching this film. I don't know if it was the weepy strings in the movie's soundtrack, the vastness of the ocean, or the ordeal of the man. But it is a film that sticks to your mind like a good meal sticks to your ribs. I recommend it heartily and highly.    Rev. Marc Axelrod

0812548094|5.0|Stones of Tears is the second in the Sword of Truth Series. Goodkind created characters you really care about and you want to win through in Wizards First Rule, and carries on that tradition in this instalment. The story is well thought out and fast paced with barely a pause between adventures - this time Richard is kidnapped by a mysterious group of women who say his magic will kill him if he doesnt become their slave. The imagination of Terry Goodkind leaves you breathless and gasping for more.  Stone of Tears has some of the creatures and characters you will find in other fantasy books, a dragon, wizards but several more never heard of before, yet has a unique way of combining magic and philosophy that is rare in teh fantasy genre. The story is overflowing with magic and adventure and creates a story with is a must for fantasy readers old and young alike. However, be aware that there are at least 8 more books in this series (of varying quality I'm sad to say) and should you read this gem, you will be hooked for the long haul.<br /><br />Relic113
0887307280|5.0|Heard a great CD program, THE E-MYTH REVISITED: WHY MOST<br /><br />SMALL BUSINESSES DON'T WORK AND WHAT TO DO ABOUT<br /><br />IT--written and read by Michael Gerber.<br /><br />Gerber, the founder of a consulting company for small businesses, had<br /><br />previously written one of my favorite business books: THE E-MYTH<br /><br />(short for entrepreneurial myth) . . . his basic premise is that just<br /><br />because you know the technical side of a business, you're not<br /><br />automatically going to be successful.<br /><br />But if you follow the model of many franchises--such as McDonald's--you<br /><br />can improve your chances . . . the key is to get a formula, then work<br /><br />that formula . . . all the time.<br /><br />I especially liked his advice on doing a little experiment if you run a<br /><br />retail store . . . ask the question that most people always ask when<br /><br />somebody enters your place of business, May I help you? . . . ask that<br /><br />for three weeks and track the results . . . then change the question<br /><br />to instead ask, Have you been here beforehand . . . when you<br /><br />track the results, you'll see that sales have increased 16%!<br /><br />That was just one of the many tidbits I gained from listening to<br /><br />this marvelous program; among the others:<br /><br />* Ask the question, What do you want to be? (As opposed to the<br /><br />question, What do I want to do?)<br /><br />* In a small business, 90% of your time should be spent on strategic<br /><br />work and only 10% on tactical work. Most businesses reverse these<br /><br />figures.<br /><br />* We don't have to motivate people, we need to inspire them.<br /><br />* Hire people by running ads not like anybody else; e.g., this<br /><br />one: We want people with passion, we want people with heart.<br /><br />When you get a bunch of people who are interested, bring them<br /><br />all at once in to a hiring seminar to listen to your story. At then end,<br /><br />then ask what one thing can they contribute to your organization.<br /><br />* Follow the example of Ritz Carlton, wherein any employee who<br /><br />gets a complaint owns it.r /> <br />* Follow the example of Ritz Carlton, wherein any employee who <br />gets a complaint owns it. <br /> <br />

B00003CX8V|5.0|Buddy Baxter (Jack Lemmon) is a meek and mild nobody in a big company who has an \\"arrangement\\" with his superiors:  They can use his apartment to entertain their ladyfriends in exchange for recommendations for his promotion.  The deal works out fine, until he discovers that his big boss (Fred MacMurray)'s girlfriend is the object of his own affection, elevator operator Fran Kubelik (Shirley MacLaine).<br /><br />\\"The Apartment\\" is a quiet, character-driven comedy about shady dealings in the world of big business, with just enough drama to tug at your heart.  It won the 1960 Best Picture Oscar, thanks to the excellent cast and honest script.  Nobody played the Everyman character as well as Lemmon.  He's involved in an unsavory situation, but is so sweet, likeable, and noble that you really care about him.  MacLaine gives an uncharacteristically subdued and thoughtful performance, and MacMurray is perfect as her heartless paramour.  The beautiful title tune is one of the loveliest movie love themes ever.  The subject matter was considered somewhat racy back then, but now it would probably be rated PG.  A sweet, smart, and entertaining movie.

B000GY729M|3.0|And in that sense, really, the whole tact they've used in promoting \\"Sam's Town\\" is genius.  \\"One of the best albums in twenty years\\", claims the lead singer.  \\"Davie Bowie is a huge fan The Killers!\\"  \\"Legendary film director Tim Burton, never before found in the realm of music video, is slated to direct The Killers' video to \\"Bones\\".  I mean, c'mon... And, for me, it worked; I was a pretty big fan of 'Hot Fuss' and I figured that, just maybe, The Killers really -- could -- release an album that somehow was absolutely exceptional.  How bold is that, anyway?  The utter confidence of such an allegation, in itself, is a pretty convincing thing; surely he would not declare express such pomposity without some sort of backing, right?  Wrong.  Truly -- and I'd have to imagine even the most devout fans of 'Sam's Town' would agree -- singer Brandon Flowers, in respect to his comment, is full of absolute sh@#, as this album probably doesn't even rank within the top hundred albums of '06 (taken into account there are what, thousands among thousands of albums released every year).  At its very best, it's enthralling and charming pop, like it's sibling 'Hot Fuss', but its overall life force is boring, uninspired, and apathetic... With such characteristics, how the in the world can we take the whole situation as anything but a ridiculous charade?  I, for one, can't seem to.    There are definitely some redeeming factors on the disc.  Interestingly, too, is that all of 'Sam's Town's highlights are in the same vein as the best stuff on 'Hot Fuss'; incredibly fast-tempo, synth-laden pop-rock songs with clinging hooks and memorable choruses.  So, the best three songs -- as is often the case in works of mediocrity -- are the first three.  'Sam's Town' is catching, if forgettable, and the bombastic, choral vocals towards the end of the song are delectable.  'When You Were Young', like both wonderful singles on 'Hot Fuss' (Mr. Brightside inparticular), is irresistible, with clever lyrics and, in Killers' fashion, a hook that digs deep.  Then -- and I'm surprised I hear very little mention of this song -- 'Bling' smacks with it's galloping drive, hopping bass line, and simply awesome use of synths backing up a chorus (I really, really dig this element within the song... definitely the highest peak the album reaches, in my opinion). Just great stuff.  And, like much of 'Hot Fuss', what makes these songs so captivating is that they reek of confidence; the type of confidence that should be evident throughout an entire album, if it really is one of the finest of the past two decades.      But then, the album slowly succumbs to flat, listenable fluff.  Totally disposable.  It's like these guys got to this point in the album and had no idea what they were going for, and the result is several confused, meddling songs that are awkward in construction and repetitive in the lack of ideas therein.  The result is tolerable, definitely, but it's also completely half-baked and not even worth going back to on repeated listens.  The tempo is slowed, and there is more emphasis on Flowers' voice (which I do like quite a bit), but the hooks are bereft of passion or wit, literally lacking anything notable within some of the songs.  'Uncle Johnny' I actually like a decent amount, but by the time 'Bones' comes on, I'm almost repulsed at how lame the music is, and I cannot BELIEVE -- this -- is the song Tim Burton is working with The Killers' on for the video.  It's so unbearably run-of-the-mill, startlingly pedestrian, with some sort of pitifully generic brass motifs you'd here in the most disposable of ska songs.  Just don't understand it; compared to a song like 'Bling', is is covered with the greatest amount of shame possible. 'My List' isn't too bad, but it isn't too good either, kicking off with a unique melody courtesy of some odd and interesting synths, and the song reverts back to the choral technique they employed in the album's title track -- and for those who haven't heard the album, think of \\"All These Things That I've Done\\" and \\"Andy, You're a Star\\" from 'Hot Fuss' -- again an appealing element that I dig but ultimately is seems almost as if it in itself -- the towering presence that it is -- is just masking the lack of worthwhile musical actually here.      \\"This River is Wild\\" is definitely the highlight of the album's dispensable second half, with its return to the styling of the initial three songs, but every time I hear it, I can't help but think \\"this sure is a lot like 'Hot Fuss'' \\"Midnight Show\\"\\".  Still, it provides for some relief.  The album then ends on a superficial note, one last time going back yet 'again' to the mammoth vocally layered chorus, which is impossible to dislike with its grandiosity but anything but impressive.  \\"Exitlude\\" seems indifferent on closing on any sort of uniqueness, following the same pattern.  Meh.    The more I think of it, the more I come to grips with how much better of an album 'Hot Fuss' really was. 'Sam's Town' just isn't very fun save for some fifteen odd minutes, and the rest comes off as little else but filler.  Note, too, I've listened to the album probably fifteen times (at least it's brief at forty four minutes -- exluding the 'bonus tracks'); while 'Hot Fuss' seemed to grow and grow on me with each subsequent listen, I think I peaked with 'Sam's Town' at about the fifth listen, with each following spin bringing forth less and less excitement, with a progressively present feeling of disinterest.  That's never a good sign.

B000GFLAI0|1.0|In his early work, Dylan set the bar for songwriting so high that for three decades, he's had no one to compete with but himself.  It may be unfair to compare his current work with his classics, but Dylan can be judged by no other standard than his own.  Unfortunately, his new record is nowhere near the mark.<br /><br />In fact, it doesn't really sound like a Dylan album.  In the early 90s, Dylan took seven years off from songwriting and released only two albums of cover songs, Good as I Been To You and World Gone Wrong.  Neither was especially interesting and proved nothing other than that Dylan could sing and play guitar professionally, which everyone knew.  Modern Times sounds much more like those cover albums, and in fact much of the material is not new.<br /><br />Does the world really need another cover of \\"Rollin' and Tumblin',\\" especially one that's six minutes long?  Dylan's version is OK, but Cream's is better, to say nothing of Muddy Waters and Robert Johnson.  \\"Someday Baby\\" is basically Muddy Waters's \\"Trouble No More\\", with slightly different lyrics.  \\"The Levee's Gonna Break\\" is apparently another re-working of a blues standard, and it's lively enough, but there's nothing new here.<br /><br />There may be original material on this record, but there's not an original note or melody to be heard.  Covers can be good, but these are humdrum versions, competently played but utterly lacking in fire.  Perhaps it's too much to expect passion from a 65-year old singer, but then, why is he making the record if he doesn't have something to say?<br /><br />Dylan's previous effort, \\"Love and Theft\\" was also wildly overpraised (the songs sounded much better in concert than on the record, so maybe there's something to Brother Bob's recent rant about recording quality), but at least there was some originality and eccentricity, something *different*, that avid Dylan fans could glom onto.  \\"Modern Times\\" is a desultory, half-hearted effort that contains nothing you haven't heard a dozen times before.  These are generic songs that could have been written by any of a hundred artists.<br /><br />I'm glad that so many people are enjoying it, but I found it painful to get through even once (in large part due to the very long and very slow ballads that bring the record to a grinding halt).<br /><br />I've been listening to Dylan for 41 years now, and it's remarkable how I never grow tired of his earlier songs.  Since \\"Blood on the Tracks\\", he's had an occasional flash of brilliance --- a song here, a song there --- and a solid album in 1997's \\"Time Out of Mind\\" --- but \\"Modern Times\\" is one of his weakest efforts, to be filed next to \\"Down in the Groove\\" and \\"Empire Burlesque.\\"g you haven't heard a dozen times before.  These are generic songs that could have been written by any of a hundred artists. <br /> <br />I'm glad that so many people are enjoying it, but I found it painful to get through even once (in large part due to the very long and very slow ballads that bring the record to a grinding halt).   <br /> <br />I've been listening to Dylan for 41 years now, and it's remarkable how I never grow tired of his earlier songs.  Since \\"Blood on the Tracks\\", he's had an occasional flash of brilliance --- a song here, a song there --- and a solid album in 1997's \\"Time Out of Mind\\" --- but \\"Modern Times\\" is one of his weakest efforts, to be filed next to \\"Down in the Groove\\" and \\"Empire Burlesque.\\" <br /> <br />
0745123953|4.0|It's good to see this series of British police procedurals getting generally better and better with each installment. This is the sixth and the main characters are well established: DCI Alan Banks, a tough but determinedly human ex-Londoner who moved to a small Yorkshire city a few years ago; his independent-minded wife, Sandra, and his two kids, now in their late teens (he has to struggle to turn loose of them); his boss, the usually kindly Superintendent Gristhorpe, a dalesman born; his old sergeant, now in comfortable exile to make room for up-and-comer Phil Richmond, a computer junkie; DC Susan Gay, smart and a hard worker, but still prickly in her junior status; and the market and tourist town of Eastvale itself, at the mouth of a dale filled with small villages, which themselves are filled with fascinating Northerners. The plots Robinson comes up with aren't Agatha Christie-type \\"cozies,\\" though. In this one, Brenda, a not-very-bright single working class mother gives up her seven-year-old daughter to a couple of supposed social workers -- a peculiarly British attitude toward educated authority figures, apparently. As the search for the abducted child gets under way, the body of a young man turns up who has been gutted. The two cases diverge, for not for long. Brenda's boyfriend, Les, is a classic lowlife petty criminal, but his acquaintances include some who are considerably more chilling. The plot is well thought out and reasonable in its construction and the action is well developed. The only annoying part, actually, is Banks's and Gristhorpe's prejudices, which don't seem to go with the rest of their personalities. I also get a little tired of \\"cop games\\" when it comes to interrogation of suspects; how can anyone fall for such nonsense in this day and age? Nevertheless, I'm looking forward to the next volume in the series.

B000002LBH|5.0|\\"Louder Than Bombs\\" is a Smiths compilation of sorts, a collection of non-album singles, B-sides and several tracks from the Smiths' first compilation \\"Hatful of Hollow\\". Many of these tracks you can't get anywhere else. Well, you can get them on \\"The World Won't Listen\\", but that's a very similar compilation to this one. <br /> <br />It's a good value collection, and a fine introduction to the band, I think. There are 24 tracks, recorded between 1984-1987, of all different styles and moods. All have fantastic guitar playing by Johnny Marr, while Andy Rourke's bass and Mike Joyce's guitar keep things catchy too. Morrissey's lyrics though, are what makes this record, and the Smiths, really special, I think. He can be witty at times, he can be warm, he can be sympathetic and he can be despairing, often all in the same song. He comes up with some great little phrases in his songs. As for subject matters, he covers all sorts of things, just as Johnny Marr covers all sorts of moods. \\"Shoplifters of the World Unite\\" lends an ear to the commercially compulsive, \\"This Night Has Opened My Eyes\\" sees a mother abandon a child, \\"Girl Afraid\\" touches on the pushy girl/passive guy relationship, and \\"You Just Haven't Earned It Yet Baby\\" (which I reckon really should have gone on to be a hit single) sums up the pain of struggling and striving, whether in attempts to find love or attempts to be famous. It's one of my favourites of the album and the band, as is \\"Rubber Ring\\", where Morrissey urges the listener not to \\"forget the songs that made you cry, and the ones that saved your life\\" and to spare a happy thought for him after such songs have helped you through tough times. If anyone else had been singing it, it might have come across as a bit arrogant, but the Smiths wrote some powerful songs, and Morrissey knew it! There's also an instrumental by Johnny Marr (\\"Oscillate Wildly\\") and a very strange, but typically Morrissey, cover song (Twinkle's \\"Golden Lights\\"). <br /> <br />Thebooklet is fairly simple, but it comes with the lyrics to all the songs, which is very nice to have for a band like the Smiths. <br /> <br />Overall, a great introduction to the band, a great addition to Smiths/Morrissey collection, and a great bunch of songs. Recommended.

Nirvana, R.E.M., Coldplay, U2 and the Red Hot Chili Peppers have already done so. Well, add Pearl Jam to the list!<br /><br />I had always loved the big hits from this album (Jeremy, Alive, Evenflow, Black), even though they got a LOT of airtime, almost too much. But this isn't perfect - Oceans and Porch could've been removed. Still, this is great alternative rock, which is as it turns out NOT an oxymoron. Eddie Veder's vocals are great, very emotional and a highlight of every song, even a couple weaker ones.

Great movie, but the disc was put together by under-achievers.  Maybe someday Criterion can do it justice.
